trans-unit.source: Represents a nonexistent value.
This class cannot be inherited.
The DBNull class represents a nonexistent value.
In a database, for example, a column in a row of a table might not contain any data whatsoever.
That is, the column is considered to not exist at all instead of merely not having a value.
A DBNull object represents the nonexistent column.
Additionally, COM interop uses the DBNull class to distinguish between a VT_NULL variant, which indicates a nonexistent value, and a VT_EMPTY variant, which indicates an unspecified value.
The DBNull type is a singleton class, which means only one DBNull object exists.
The <xref:System.DBNull.Value?displayProperty=fullName> member represents the sole DBNull object.

<xref:System.DBNull.Value?displayProperty=fullName>can be used to explicitly assign a nonexistent value to a database field, although most ADO.NET data providers automatically assign values of DBNull when a field does not have a valid value.
You can determine whether a value retrieved from a database field is a DBNull value by passing the value of that field to the `DBNull.Value.Equals` method.
However, some languages and database objects supply methods that make it easier to determine whether the value of a database field is <xref:System.DBNull.Value?displayProperty=fullName>.

These include the Visual Basic `IsDBNull` function, the <xref:System.Convert.IsDBNull%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, the <xref:System.Data.DataTableReader.IsDBNull%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, and the <xref:System.Data.IDataRecord.IsDBNull%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
Do not confuse the notion of `null` in an object-oriented programming language with a DBNull object.
In an object-oriented programming language, `null` means the absence of a reference to an object.
DBNull represents an uninitialized variant or nonexistent database column.
Implements the <xref href="System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable"></xref> interface and returns the data needed to serialize the <xref href="System.DBNull"></xref> object.
A <xref href="System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo"></xref> object containing information required to serialize the <xref href="System.DBNull"></xref> object.
A <xref:System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext> object containing the source and destination of the serialized stream associated with the <xref href="System.DBNull"></xref> object.

Converts the current <xref href="System.DBNull"></xref> object to the specified type.
Three conversions are supported: If the `type` parameter specifies <xref:System.Object> or <xref:System.DBNull>, the return value is the current <xref:System.DBNull> object itself.
If the `type` parameter specifies <xref:System.String>, the return value is the string returned by the <xref:System.DBNull.ToString%2A> method.
The type to convert the current <xref href="System.DBNull"></xref> object to.
An object that implements the <xref:System.IFormatProvider> interface and is used to augment the conversion.
If <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref> is specified, format information is obtained from the current culture.
The boxed equivalent of the current <xref href="System.DBNull"></xref> object, if that conversion is supported; otherwise, an exception is thrown and no value is returned.
This conversion is not supported for the <xref href="System.DBNull"></xref> type.

-or- <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref> to obtain the format information from the current locale setting of the operating system.
An empty string (<xref:System.String?displayProperty=fullName>).
Represents the sole instance of the <xref href="System.DBNull"></xref> class.
<xref:System.DBNull> is a singleton class, which means only this instance of this class can exist.
If a database field has missing data, you can use the Value property to explicitly assign a <xref:System.DBNull> object value to the field.
However, most data providers do this automatically.
To evaluate database fields to determine whether their values are <xref:System.DBNull>, you can pass the field value to the `DBNull.Value.Equals` method.
However, this method is rarely used because there are a number of other ways to evaluate a database field for missing data.

These include the Visual Basic `IsDBNull` function, the <xref:System.Convert.IsDBNull%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, the <xref:System.Data.DataTableReader.IsDBNull%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, the <xref:System.Data.IDataRecord.IsDBNull%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, and several other methods.
To be added.
